conversations.content: Ephemeral Beauty: Part One
The gentle Poli'ahu dwelled in the ice and was beloved by humans for her generosity—though this caused some to underestimate her power.
Rumors of the many treasures she had accumulated over her long life soon reached the ears of thieves who sought to steal them for their own personal gain.
One day, they snuck into her lair as she slept. The rumors were true: beside the slumbering Poli'ahu, they found a mountain of crystals, each as clear as daylight.
Elated, the thieves rushed to ferry the treasure out of the nest, but their footsteps woke the great dragon.
Poli'ahu gazed at each of the thieves in turn. ＂You have great audacity, sneaking into a dragon's den,＂ she said. ＂I hope you are prepared to face the consequences.＂
The thieves trembled in fear, but soon remembered that Poli'ahu never killed humans. They then groveled before her, a ready excuse on each of their lips.
＂This is a misunderstanding! We are but art dealers come to discuss business! You have such a fine collection, we were hoping you'd tell us where you stole these treasures.＂
Too late the thieves realized what they had said. Surely the dragon would unleash her wrath upon them for treating her like a common criminal—but her gaze was calm.
＂Poli'ahu never kills anyone,＂ thought the thieves again. ＂We're going home, and we're taking all of this treasure with us!＂
Ephemeral Beauty: Part Two
＂We were hoping you'd tell us where you stole these treasures,＂ said the thieves, who themselves had come to steal the dragon's treasure. Yet Poli'ahu remained placid.
＂You think me a thief?＂ laughed Poli'ahu. ＂Alas, all that you see here I have made myself as a way to spend the long, lonely hours.＂
The thieves quickly showered Poli'ahu in praise. ＂This is all your creation? Incredible! We never knew there were such artisans among dragonkind!＂
＂You must allow people to see these works of art!＂ they said. When the dragon said she did not wish for that much company, they offered a solution...
＂We can take your works into town and display them there,＂ chuckled the thieves. ＂Then all will know the splendor of the great Poli'ahu!＂
The dragon worried that the beauty of her treasures would be lost in the outside world, but the thieves assured her that beauty was a universal concept.
＂Well, if you insist,＂ said Poli'ahu softly. ＂Take whatever you like. Just be sure everything is returned in a week's time, lest you regret it.＂
The triumphant thieves returned to town and immediately set about selling Poli'ahu's treasures to various aristocrats.
Every last crystal they sold, however, soon melted away—for they were made not of crystal, but of ice.
The ice could not maintain its form outside of Poli'ahu's domain. When this fact was discovered, the enraged aristocrats made the thieves pay with their very lives.
Dragons are shrewd creatures and  slow to anger, but humans would do well to remember that they are only permitted to live by their mercy.
